summary: This document is an email chain from August 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing the handling of Touhy requests (requests for government information) from an Epstein victim involved in civil litigation. The emails debate disclosure procedures, potential Giglio implications, coordination with other districts (S.D. Fla., N.D. Ga.), and interactions with the victim's attorney, Roberta Kaplan.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney representing an Epstein victim in civil litigation against Epstein's estate; the initial Touhy request letter was sent to her.

events.title: Touhy Request Giglio Discussion
events.description: Internal SDNY email discussion about whether Touhy communications with an Epstein victim (referred to as 'El' or 'W') are disclosable as Giglio information (material affecting witness credibility).

events.title: Maxwell Team Approval of Touhy Response
events.description: SDNY prosecutors note that Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team has signed off on an updated letter responding to an Epstein victim's Touhy request.

events.title: Identification of Jane Doe
events.description: An email states 'we fully know that Jane Doe is [redacted/implied name]' in the context of a Touhy request, confirming the identity of a victim/witness.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) was handling Touhy requests from Epstein victims involved in civil litigation, with internal debates about procedure and disclosure.
Prosecutors coordinated with Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team ('the Maxwell team') on the response to a victim's Touhy request, indicating cooperation or notification in the criminal case.
Internal concerns were raised that Touhy communications with an Epstein victim could be considered Giglio material (potentially impeaching information) that might need to be disclosed.
The SDNY did not possess files from the U.S. Attorney's Office in S.D. Fla. related to Epstein's prior non-prosecution agreement, to avoid conflict and discovery issues.
A victim's identity (referred to as 'Jane Doe' in litigation) was known to the SDNY prosecutors, as indicated in an April 2020 email.
